SENT.plain: PURPOSE: To describe the hemodynamic effect of oral acetazolamide administration on ocular perfusion in a patient with pseudotumor cerebri associated with Crohn disease
METHODS: A 20-year-old woman with a 5-year history of Crohn disease presented with a 2-week history of headache and blurred vision in both eyes
Fluorescein angiography showed a profound delay in retinal and choroidal perfusion
Lumbar puncture showed an opening pressure of 320 mm water
Therapy was initiated with oral acetazolamide 750 mg per day
RESULTS: A subjective improvement of symptoms was noted over 4 days
Repeat fluorescein angiography showed resolution of the ocular perfusion deficit
No recurrent symptoms were noted 19 months after cessation of therapy
CONCLUSIONS: Crohn disease may present with pseudotumor cerebri and severe ocular perfusion deficits that are reversible with oral acetazolamide therapy
